snippet: Forced individual arbitration often bears little resemblance to court: The rules tend to favor businesses, and judges and juries are replaced by arbitrators whose rulings are difficult to appeal.
abstract: New York Times investigation finds thousands of businesses in last ten years have pushed for and use private arbitration, which greatly favors businesses over their clients and acts essentially as alternate system of justice; companies have been adding arbitration clauses to employment or consumer contracts that are rarely ever read; use of arbitration became even more desirable for companies following 2011 Supreme Court decision that allowed them to use such clauses to prevent class-action lawsuits (Series: Beware the Fine Print).
lead_paragraph: Forced individual arbitration often bears little resemblance to court: The rules tend to favor businesses, and judges and juries are replaced by arbitrators whose rulings are difficult to appeal.

headline.main: In Arbitration, a ‘Privatization of the Justice System’
